intro: Galium × simonii, commonly known as the creeping wood-sorrel, is a hybrid plant belonging to the Rubiaceae family. It is characterized by its low-growing habit, with prostrate stems that often root at the nodes. The plant produces small, white or pale yellow flowers arranged in clusters, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are heart-shaped and have a distinctive veining pattern, while its stems are covered in fine, soft hairs. Galium × simonii is often found in moist, shaded areas such as woodlands and stream banks.
